tn.text: "came to Beersheba"
"Yes, I am listening"
It was common to use the phrase "go down" when speaking of traveling from Canaan to Egypt.

tn.ref: I will make you a great nation
tn.text: Here "you" is singular and refers to Jacob. This "you" also stands for Israel's descendants that will become a large nation. AT: "I will give you many descendants, and they will become a great nation" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"to Egypt"

tn.ref: I will surely bring you up again
tn.text: The promise was made to Jacob, but the promise would be fulfilled to all of Israel's descendants. AT: "I will surely bring your descendants out of Egypt again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
It was common to use the word "up" when speaking about traveling from Egypt to Canaan.

tn.ref: and Joseph will close your eyes with his own hand
tn.text: The phrase "close you eyes with his own hand" is a way of saying that Joseph will be present when Israel dies and it will be Joseph who will close Jacob's eyelids at the time of his death. AT: "And Joseph will even be present with you at the time of your death" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
It was a custom to pull down the eyelids when a person died with their eyes open. The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"set out from"
"Carts" are wagons with two or four wheels. Animals pull the carts. See how you translated "carts" in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:45:19|45:19]].
"they had acquired" (UDB) or "they had gained"
"Jacob brought with him"
"his grandsons"
"his granddaughters"
This refers to the names of the people that the author is about to list.
"of Israel's family members"

tn.ref: Hanoch and Pallu and Hezron and Carmi ... Jemuel, Jamin, Ohad, Jachin, Zohar, and Shaul ... Gershon, Kohath, and Merari
tn.text: These are all names of men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
These were the sons of Judah by his wife, Shua. See how you translated these names in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:38:03|38:3-5]].
These were the sons of Judah by his daughter-in-law, Tamar. See how you translated these names in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:38:29|38:29-30]].

tn.ref: Hezron ... Hamul ... Tola, Puvah, Lob ... Shimron ... Sered, Elon ... Jahleel
tn.text: These are all names of men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of Leah's daughter. See how you translated this name in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:30:19|30:21]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: His sons and his daughters numbered thirty-three
tn.text: three** - Here "sons" and "daughters" refer to Jacob's sons, daughters, and grandchildren related to Leah. AT: "Altogether he had 33 sons, daughters, and grandchildren" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: Ziphion ... Haggi, Shuni ... Ezbon, Er, Arodi ... Areli ... Imnah ... Ishvah, Ishvi ... Beriah ... Heber ... Malchiel
tn.text: These are the names of men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of a woman. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of Leah's female servant. See how you translated this name in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:29:23|29:24]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: These sons she bore to Jacob—sixteen in all
tn.text: This refers to 16 children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren that were related to Zilpah. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
"Asenath" is the name of the woman whom Pharaoh gave to Joseph as his wife. See how you translated this is [[:en:bible:notes:gen:41:44|41:45]].  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"Potiphera" is the father of Asenath. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:41:44|41:45]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

On is a city, also called Heliopolis, which was "the City of the Sun" and the center of worship of the sun god Ra. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:41:44|41:45]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: Bela, Becher, Ashbel, Gera, Naaman, Ehi, Rosh, Muppim, Huppim, and Ard
tn.text: These are names of men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This refers to the 14 sons and grandsons related to Rachel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
These are the names of men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of Rachel's female servant. See how you translated this name in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:29:28|29:29]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This refers to the 7 children and grandchildren related to Bilhah. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
six** - "66" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
"70" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: to show the way before him to Goshen
tn.text: "to show them the way to Goshen"

tn.ref: Joseph prepared his chariot and went up
tn.text: Here "Joseph" stands for his servants. AT: "Joseph's servants prepared his chariot and Joseph went up" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The phrase "went up" is used because Joseph is traveling to a higher elevation to meet his father. AT: "went to meet Israel"

tn.ref: hugged his neck, and wept on his neck a long time
tn.text: "put his arms around his father, and wept for a long time"
"Now I am ready to die" or "Now I will die happy"

tn.ref: since I have seen your face, that you are still alive
tn.text: Here "face" stands for the entire person. Jacob was expressing joy at seeing Joseph. AT: "since I have seen you alive again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "house" stands for his family. AT: "his father's family" or "his father's household" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: I will go up and tell Pharaoh
tn.text: It was common to use the phrase "go up" when referring to someone going to speak with someone with greater authority. AT: "I will go tell Pharaoh"

tn.ref: tell Pharaoh, saying, 'My brothers ... all that they have.'
tn.text: This is a quotation within a quotation. It can be stated as an indirect quotation. AT: "tell Pharaoh that my brothers ... all that they have" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])
This phrase is used here to mark an important event that is about to happen in the story. If your language has a way for doing this, you could consider using it here.

tn.ref: and asks, 'What is your occupation?' that you should say
tn.text: This is a quotation within a quotation. It can be stated as an indirect quotation. AT: "and asks you about what kind of work you do, you should say" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])

tn.ref: you should say, 'Your servants have ... both we, and our forefathers.'
tn.text: This is a quotation within a quotation. It can be stated as an indirect quotation. AT: "you should say that you have ... both you and your forefathers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])

Joseph's family are to refer to themselves as "your servants" when they speak to Pharaoh. This is a formal way of speaking to someone with greater authority. It can be stated in the first person. AT: "We, your servants" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

tn.ref: every shepherd is an abomination to the Egyptians
tn.text: The abstract noun "abomination" can be translated with the adjective "disgusting." AT: "Egyptians think shepherds are disgusting" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
